newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine peso closes down on U.S. rate fears.
newsitem.headline: Philippine peso closes down on U.S. rate fears.

text.p: The Philippine peso closed lower on Tuesday at 26.355 from 26.344 in an actively traded market as banks positioned on the dollar ahead of a possible rise in U.S. interest rates, traders said.
The U.S. Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) is set to meet on Tuesday.
Traders said the Central Bank had to intervene by selling about $13 million at 26.355 and later at $43 million at 26.36.
But the Central Bank's move to sell dollars at 26.36 pesos added nervousness to the market and caused some arbitrage investors to close their positions, foreign bank traders said.
"This is the first time from January that the Central Bank gave an offer rate of 26.36," a dealer said.
Dealers said banks also experienced increased corporate demand for dollars to meet their importation requirements.
Market volume tripled to $314.9 million from $98 million.
On Wednesday, the peso's direction will be dictated by the decision of the FOMC and a possible adjustment in the Philippine Central Bank's overnight rates, traders said.
